common_locations: Norris, Canyon, and Old Faithful areas
facts: Makes up nearly 80% of Yellowstone’s forest cover.
Has serotinous cones that require fire to open and release seeds.
Thin bark allows quick growth but little fire resistance.
Can grow in poor, rocky soils.
Supports bird species like Clark’s Nutcracker and mammals like red squirrels.
purpose: Dominant tree species that regenerates quickly after fire and provides critical wildlife habitat. Its success is due to fire adaptation, low soil nutrient requirements, and prolific seeding.

common_locations: Subalpine forests around Canyon and Mount Washburn
facts: Tall evergreen with sharp, square needles.
Found in colder, wetter areas at high elevations.
Shade-tolerant and slow-growing.
Bark is scaly and gray-brown.
Seeds are an important food for squirrels and birds.
purpose: Plays a vital role in subalpine ecosystems, offering shade, moisture retention, and wildlife food. Thrives due to cold tolerance and shade adaptability.

common_locations: Northern slopes of the park, especially Gardiner Basin and Mammoth
facts: Recognizable by its deeply furrowed bark and pointed cones.
Fire-resistant due to thick bark.
Grows best on dry, south-facing slopes.
Essential for elk winter cover.
Popular with nesting birds like owls and eagles.
purpose: Survives fire and drought, dominates drier forest edges, and provides cover for wildlife, contributing to ecosystem stability.

facts: Silvery leaves with a strong scent.
Important winter forage for elk and pronghorn.
Has deep roots that access water during drought.
Releases chemicals that suppress competing plants.
Supports sagebrush-dependent birds like the Brewer’s sparrow.
purpose: Anchor species of Yellowstone’s steppe. Succeeds in arid zones due to deep roots and allelopathy, and supports unique sage-steppe biodiversity.

common_locations: Open hillsides, Lamar and Blacktail plateaus
facts: Important forage for bison, elk, and pronghorn.
Grows in clumps instead of forming sod.
Drought-resistant and cold-hardy.
Deep-rooted and prevents erosion.
Can resprout quickly after fire or grazing.
purpose: Key grassland species. Success comes from resilience to grazing and drought, helping stabilize soils and feed large herbivores.

facts: Leaves tremble in wind due to flattened petioles.
Aspens regenerate via root suckers, forming large clones.
Provide food and habitat for birds, deer, and elk.
Fall color is a golden yellow.
Often found near water or along meadow edges.
purpose: Aspens add diversity and fire resilience to forests. Their rapid regeneration allows quick recovery after disturbances.

facts: Narrow, spire-shaped tree adapted to heavy snow.
Needles are soft, flat, and bluish-green.
Prefers cool, moist environments.
Provides cover for wildlife like snowshoe hares.
Slow-growing but shade-tolerant.
purpose: Forms part of high-elevation climax communities and provides winter shelter for many animals. Thrives in snow-covered, cold regions.

facts: Low-growing with trifoliate leaves and white flowers.
Produces small but flavorful red berries.
Spreads via runners and seeds.
Flowers attract bees and butterflies.
Fruits are eaten by birds and mammals.
purpose: Supports pollinators and frugivores. Its ground-covering nature helps reduce erosion and thrives in disturbed soils.

common_locations: Open grasslands and roadsides throughout park
facts: Feathery leaves and white umbrella-like flowers.
Known for medicinal uses by Native peoples.
Highly drought-tolerant.
Blooms from late spring into summer.
Attracts butterflies and beneficial insects.
purpose: Important pollinator plant and erosion controller. Thrives in disturbed and dry areas, promoting ecological balance.

common_locations: Dry slopes, forest edges, near Mammoth and Tower
facts: Shrub with white spring flowers and edible purple berries.
Food source for bears, birds, and people.
Flowers emerge before leaves in spring.
Part of the rose family.
Can resprout after fire or browsing.
purpose: Vital browse and berry source for wildlife. Its tough roots and quick regrowth help it flourish in fire-prone landscapes.

facts: Tall stalk with pink to magenta flowers.
Colonizes rapidly after fire.
Named for its growth after wildfires.
Supports bees, butterflies, and hummingbirds.
Leaves can be used in teas.
purpose: Pioneer species after disturbance. Builds soil and attracts pollinators, helping kickstart ecological succession.

facts: Evergreen groundcover with red berries.
Flowers are pale pink urns in spring.
Berries are eaten by bears and birds.
Drought-tolerant and low-growing.
Used in herbal medicine traditionally.
purpose: Groundcover stabilizing soils and supporting wildlife. Survives harsh alpine and dry slope environments.

common_locations: Rocky ridges, dry valleys, west of park
facts: Montana’s state flower.
Succulent leaves and striking pink blooms.
Blooms in spring after snowmelt.
Used as a food and medicine source by tribes.
Dormant most of the year, except for bloom.
purpose: An iconic plant adapted to harsh dry climates. Its short blooming cycle conserves water and energy in tough soil.

facts: Tall plant with bright yellow flower plumes.
Often misattributed to causing allergies.
Supports bees, beetles, and butterflies.
Blooming peaks in August–September.
Tolerant of poor, sandy soils.
purpose: Key late-season pollinator support. Thrives in disturbed meadows and supports declining insect populations.

facts: Delicate blue flowers bloom each morning.
Used for textiles and cordage historically.
Grows in clumps with slender stems.
Pollinated by native bees.
Tolerates drought and high sun exposure.
purpose: Pioneering flower that stabilizes dry soils. Attracts pollinators and offers visual diversity to dryland habitats.

facts: Yellow daisy-like flowers bloom in early summer.
Known for medicinal and anti-inflammatory uses.
Spreads via underground rhizomes.
Deer and elk browse it occasionally.
Leaves are soft and heart-shaped.
purpose: Provides herbal and wildlife value. Rhizomatous growth lets it thrive in forest understories and recover after trampling.

facts: Large broad leaves with tightly packed flowers.
Highly toxic to humans and animals.
Often confused with edible plants.
Grows 3–6 feet tall.
Part of the lily family.
purpose: Important in wetland ecosystems despite toxicity. Avoided by grazers, it competes well in saturated soils.

common_locations: Forest edges, Gibbon River, Norris area
facts: Small shrub with white berries and pink flowers.
Berries persist into winter and feed birds.
Tolerates cold, drought, and browsing.
Branches provide nesting cover for birds.
Waxy berries are mildly toxic to humans.
purpose: Low-maintenance wildlife plant. Its berries and shelter support songbirds, and it thrives under multiple stressors.

common_locations: Moist woodlands, near streams and roadsides
facts: Broad, maple-like leaves and soft red berries.
Berries are edible and favored by bears.
Flowers are large and white with five petals.
Grows in thick, spreading clumps.
Deciduous and shade-tolerant.
purpose: Important bear forage and understory plant. Spreads via rhizomes and thrives in shady, moist environments.
